body:
Using your example, I was unable to make it work with Helm 2.

```
><> ./bin/helm upgrade --install mychart incubator/raw --version 0.1.0 --namespace default --values myvalues.yaml
Release "mychart" does not exist. Installing it now.
Error: release mychart failed: Secret "mytest" is invalid: data[.dockerconfigjson]: Invalid value: "<secret contents redacted>": invalid character 'e' in literal true (expecting 'r')
```

The following `myvalues.yaml` worked for Helm 2 and Helm 3, however it failed with the same issue as demonstrated in helm/helm#4670.

```
><> ./bin/helm upgrade --install mychart incubator/raw --version 0.1.0 --namespace default --values myvalues.yaml
Release "mychart" does not exist. Installing it now.
Error: release mychart failed: no objects visited
```

And for Helm 3:

```
><> helm upgrade --install mychart incubator/raw --version 0.1.0 --namespace default --values myvalues.yaml
Release "mychart" does not exist. Installing it now.
Error: no objects visited
```

Perhaps it's the chart itself that's causing the error?

Actually that's my bad. It's because there are no resources being rendered.

```
><> helm template incubator/raw --version 0.1.0 --namespace default --values myvalues.yaml

```

In either case, perhaps there's an issue with the chart itself that triggers the error.

If you can provide an example that works for Helm 2 but doesn't work for Helm 3, that would be appreciated.

Yep. Looks like a chart issue. If I change resources.yaml to the following:

```
{{- $template := fromYaml (include "raw.resource" .) -}}
{{- range .Values.resources }}
---
{{ toYaml (merge $template .) -}}
{{- end }}
{{- range $i, $t := .Values.templates }}
---
{{ toYaml (merge (tpl $t $ | fromYaml) $template) -}}
{{- end }}
```

The chart renders fine.

```
><> helm template ./raw --values myvalues.yaml 
---
# Source: raw/templates/resources.yaml
apiVersion: v1
kind: Secret
metadata:
  labels:
    app: raw
    chart: raw-0.2.3
    heritage: Helm
    release: RELEASE-NAME
  name: mytest
stringData:
  .dockerconfigjson: test
type: kubernetes.io/dockerconfigjson
```

That modification works for Helm 2 as well.

```
><> ./bin/helm template ./raw/ --values myvalues.yaml 
---
# Source: raw/templates/resources.yaml

---
apiVersion: v1
kind: Secret
metadata:
  labels:
    app: raw
    chart: raw-0.2.3
    heritage: Tiller
    release: release-name
  name: mytest
stringData:
  .dockerconfigjson: test
type: kubernetes.io/dockerconfigjson


```

Transferring to helm/charts as this appears to be a bug with the chart itself, not with Helm 3.

@bacongobbler, sorry, I removed some sensitive data from the initial `myvalues.yaml` file, which probably caused the invalid resource error.

Here's an updated file which works with helm2, but doesn't work with helm3:

`myvalues.yaml`
```
resources:
  - apiVersion: v1
    kind: Secret
    type: kubernetes.io/dockerconfigjson
    metadata:
      name: docker-monitoring-release-flb
    stringData:
      .dockerconfigjson: "{\"auths\":{ \"docker2-monitoring-release-local.test.com\":{\"auth\":\"dXNlcjpwYXNzd29yZAo=\"}}}"
```

**Helm2**
```
❯ helm upgrade --install docker-monitoring-release-flb incubator/raw --version 0.1.0 --namespace default --values myvalues.yaml

Release "docker-monitoring-release-flb" has been upgraded.
LAST DEPLOYED: Thu Oct 10 01:23:44 2019
NAMESPACE: default
STATUS: DEPLOYED
```

**Helm3:**
```
❯ helm3 upgrade --install docker-monitoring-release-flb incubator/raw --version 0.1.0 --namespace default --values myvalues.yaml

Release "docker-monitoring-release-flb" does not exist. Installing it now.
Error: template: raw/templates/resources.yaml:4:12: executing "raw/templates/resources.yaml" at <merge . $template>: error calling merge: reflect.Value.MapIndex: value of type interface {} is not assignable to type string
```

Hmm. I can't seem to figure it out, but something in how the values object is being merged into is causing the error.

Re-transferring back to helm/helm as this may be a regression issue.

Let me know if you're able to find something in helm's code that may be causing the issue.

issue.title: Helm3 doesn't automatically create namespace
issue.body:
Helm3 doesn't automatically create namespace - see https://v3.helm.sh/docs/faq/#automatically-creating-namespaces

How can we solve this with helmfile, so that we don't have to manually create them?

body: Thanks, @bacongobbler. Glad that you managed to replicate the issue on your end as well. Not familiar with the helm code base (or `go` for that matter); hope someone can chime in

Probably this is due to possible changes to `fromYaml` that made it to return `map[interface{}]interface{}` nested in `map[string]interface{}` where it had been returning `map[string]interface{}` nested in `map[string]interface{}` in helm v2.

v2:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22009/66533168-ec89b380-eb4c-11e9-9bc5-d31f03a48ef2.png)

v3:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22009/66533129-c82dd700-eb4c-11e9-99e4-edbebdcc22c3.png)

Is anyone aware of such change?

issue.title: fix(v3): fix type error while merging map loaded with `fromYaml` template func

labels.name: size/S
labels.description: Denotes a PR that changes 10-29 lines, ignoring generated files.

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Categorizes issue or PR as related to a bug.

labels.name: v3.x
labels.description: Issues and Pull Requests related to the major version v3

issue.body:
Closes #6626

**What this PR does / why we need it**:

Helm v3 has a regression in merging dicts loaded with the `fromYaml` template function.

In my manual testing, it turned out to be due to that in #6016 we missed migrating helm-specific (non-sprig) template functions to use the new yaml package(sigs.k8s.io/yaml). Perhaps it was intentional? But the inconsistency seems to have broken it anyway.

This changes the import path to that of the new yaml package.

I've manually verified this to work as expecited, fixing the issue described in #6626.

**Special notes for your reviewer**:

**If applicable**:
- [ ] this PR contains documentation
- [x] this PR contains unit tests
- [x] this PR has been tested for backwards compatibility

body: #6630 seems to fix this. Could anyone test it out?
Thank you SO MUCH @mumoshu for identifying the fix, providing a patch, AND adding test cases to cover this case! ❤️
